prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want to give back my adopted son?
When my husband and I found out that I’m infertile we decided that we would still have children somehow. Given my medical issues, in vitro wasn’t really an option. My husband wanted to try surrogacy but in the end I pointed out that there are so many unwanted children in the world that perhaps adoption was the most selfless route. 

It was a long, difficult road but we finally were able to adopt an adorable little boy from Haiti. 

He was three when we got him and he’s six years old now. From the outset, he’s been prone to violent tantrums and he’s getting stronger. He’s grown so destructive we had to strip his room down so that it’s just the bare essentials. 

We have tried being firm, being soft, giving discipline, giving positive reinforcement, ignoring, being attentive. He’s been working with a therapist for the past year and a half. He’s actually fairly well behaved there. 

At home and school, it’s a completely different story. He’s only in first grade and already at risk of expulsion. He’s kicked his teacher. He used play scissors to cut a little girl’s ponytail off when her back was turned (now he’s lost all privileges to use them). He flooded the toilets by flushing his own clothes. 

What’s worse is that I don’t think he feels anything for me or for my husband. He behaves slightly better than my husband than for me but my husband is naturally loud and boisterous, even when he’s not angry,so maybe that’s intimidating. But with me, it’s just a nightmare. I’ve been punched, spat on, kicked, slapped, clawed. All by a child that I do everything for. He can be very calm and sweet but he turns so quickly. 

Although he’s somewhat better after therapy, it doesn’t last long. He’s been diagnosed with reactive attachment disorder, and unfortunately it’s not something that can really be cured. 

I’m trying to talk myself out of feeling this way. Telling myself that good people don’t consider what I’m considering. I’ve visited all kinds of parenting blogs and mommy forums and adoption subs (including the one here on my alt account).

I’m just exhausted emotionally and physically. I guess I’m here because of my masochistic tendencies. I welcome your honesty. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of this "AITA" post is in the wrong for considering giving back their adopted son. The situation is pretty intense. The parents adopted a three-year-old from Haiti now six, dealing with severe behavioral issues, including violence towards the parents and others. The kid has reactive attachment disorder, which is hard to treat.

First, I need to consider the parents' perspective. They've tried everything—firm and soft approaches, discipline, therapy. The child is destructive, in trouble at school, and physically abusive. The mother feels emotionally and physically drained. Reactive attachment disorder is a real challenge, and they've been through a lot. 

On the other hand, adoption is a big commitment, especially for older kids who may have had difficult pasts. The parents decided on adoption as the selfless route, but now they're facing these challenges. They're not giving up without trying, but maybe they feel it's too much. 

But is it their fault? Are they in the wrong? They didn't abandon the child lightly. They've given him a home, therapy, support. The child's behaviors are beyond their control despite all efforts. The parents' well-being and safety matter too. If the child is abusive, the parents might feel they can't provide a safe environment anymore. 

However, some might argue that once you adopt, you can't give up so easily. But that's a moral stance. The question is about whether they're "in the wrong." Legally, they might have to follow certain procedures to return the child, but morally? The parents' health is important. If they're being physically harmed, they have a right to protect themselves. 

Also, the child might need a different environment where they can get more specialized care. The parents could be doing the right thing by seeking a placement where he can receive better support. So maybe they're not in the wrong. Their intentions are to help the child but also to survive the situation. 

But maybe they should have known the risks before adopting. However, it's one thing to know the possibility and another to experience it. They might have expected challenges but not to this extent. 

In conclusion, the parents are in a tough spot. They're considering giving back the child out of necessity, not malice. Their safety and mental health are valid concerns. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
